newsitem.title: MEXICO: Banco de Mexico outlines 1997 monetary policy aims.
newsitem.headline: Banco de Mexico outlines 1997 monetary policy aims.

text.p: Banco de Mexico said on Thursday it was targetting a 20.58 billion peso rise in the monetary base by year-end 1997 to 104.57 billion pesos, and a 745 million peso drop in net domestic credit.

"That decline in domestic credit, if it happens, will not imply a restriction on the economy, because the shrinkage of the (amount of) pesos that results from the drop will be compensated by the injection of money coming from the purchase of foreign exchange by the central bank," it said in a summary of its 1997 monetary policy position.
It said net international assets were due to rise.
"Banco de Mexico plans to raise its net international assets by at least $2.5 billion during 1997," it said.

The bank gave itself the option of continuing its policy of altering domestic credit conditions in the banking system to maintain "order" in the foreign exchange and money markets. But it said that once shifts were made and the situation had improved it would return to a neutral posture.

It reiterated that the "main objective" of the 1997 program was to "help lower the inflation rate to 15 percent". In line with other government policies, this would probably lead to a real increase of gross domestic product of above four percent over the year, it said.
